elements.content: Conversion from CO2 to the more desirable and valuable C2+ products under neutral conditions is important for the development of energy and the environment, but it is a challenging work. In this work, we demonstrate that the bi-copper sites on the crystal surface of a metal–organic framework Cu-HITP (HITP = 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene) are very suitable for catalyzing the low-energy pathway of *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH. The in situ infrared spectroscopy, theoretic calculations, and controlled experiments show that polydopamine coating of Cu-HITP could provide a carbon dioxide reduction reaction-favored local environment with proton sources and hydrogen-bond donors around the bi-copper active sites to promote *CO hydrogenation and stabilize the key intermediates (*COH and *OCCOH), resulting in a high selectivity of the C2+ reduced products [Faradaic efficiency (C2+) of 75(3)%, Faradaic efficiency (C2H4) of 51(1)%] in the KHCO3 electrolyte. This work provides an insight into the catalytic activity on the surface of metal–organic frameworks and the local environment for electroreduction of CO2 to C2+ products.
elements.clean_text: Conversion from CO2 to the more desirable and valuable C2+ products under neutral conditions is important for the development of energy and the environment, but it is a challenging work. In this work, we demonstrate that the bi-copper sites on the crystal surface of a metal-organic framework Cu-HITP (HITP = 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene) are very suitable for catalyzing the low-energy pathway of *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH. The in situ infrared spectroscopy, theoretic calculations, and controlled experiments show that polydopamine coating of Cu-HITP could provide a carbon dioxide reduction reaction-favored local environment with proton sources and hydrogen-bond donors around the bi-copper active sites to promote *CO hydrogenation and stabilize the key intermediates (*COH and *OCCOH), resulting in a high selectivity of the C2+ reduced products [Faradaic efficiency (C2+) of 75(3)%, Faradaic efficiency (C2H4) of 51(1)%] in the KHCO3 electrolyte. This work provides an insight into the catalytic activity on the surface of metal-organic frameworks and the local environment for electroreduction of CO2 to C2+ products.

elements.content: The use of surplus electricity to reduce CO2 into valued chemicals and fuels is of revolutionary significance to the global environment and sustainable carbon cycle. However, because the catalytic activity and reduced product selectivity are poor in aqueous solution, it is a challenging task. Generally, catalysts with a suitable electronic structure can reduce CO2 in water with high Faradaic efficiency. Moreover, only two-electron C1 products (CO and HCOOH) are usually obtained because these products have more facile kinetics. Deep reduction of CO2 to the value-added or energy-dense products, especially C2+ products (C2H4, C2H6, CH3CH2OH, and CH3COOH), is more desirable, but usually, the overpotentials are significantly higher and selectivities are poor. Also, the main challenge to yield C2+ products with high selectivity lies in promoting C–C coupling.
elements.clean_text: The use of surplus electricity to reduce CO2 into valued chemicals and fuels is of revolutionary significance to the global environment and sustainable carbon cycle. However, because the catalytic activity and reduced product selectivity are poor in aqueous solution, it is a challenging task. Generally, catalysts with a suitable electronic structure can reduce CO2 in water with high Faradaic efficiency. Moreover, only two-electron C1 products (CO and HCOOH) are usually obtained because these products have more facile kinetics. Deep reduction of CO2 to the value-added or energy-dense products, especially C2+ products (C2H4, C2H6, CH3CH2OH, and CH3COOH), is more desirable, but usually, the overpotentials are significantly higher and selectivities are poor. Also, the main challenge to yield C2+ products with high selectivity lies in promoting C-C coupling.

elements.content: In the process of the electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), strong enough binding of the *CO intermediate on the catalytic surface is required to establish sufficient coverage for further reduction or C–C coupling. Experimentally, it was verified that regulating the electronic structure of copper could stabilize the *CO intermediate. Introducing ligands with strong hydrogen-bonding groups (amino and phenolic hydroxyl groups) around metal active sites is another way to stabilize the key intermediates (*COH and *OCCOH). Among them, phenolic hydroxyl groups are not only hydrogen-bond donors but also proton sources to adjust proton delivery and promote hydrogenation. Theoretical calculations showed that there are two potential reaction pathways for the formation of the C–C bond, namely, (a) the dimerization of two *CO and (b) the coupling of *CO with a *CO hydrogenation product (e.g., *COH). In fact, the barrier of a *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH is 0.87 eV (U = 0 V), which is much lower than that (1.15 eV) of *CO dimerization. Thus, adjusting proton delivery to hydrogenate *CO into *COH and then coupling with an adjacent *CO species are beneficial to reduce the energy barrier for forming a C–C bond. Carefully analyzing the molecular structure of the *OCCOH intermediate shows that the C–C distance is about 1.55 Å, and the ∠C–C site is about 108–120°, so the ideal distance between two active sites for forming the *OCCOH species is within 2.78–3.56 Å. Therefore, introducing amino and phenolic hydroxyl groups around the active sites with an appropriate distance may markedly promote the C–C coupling synergistically (c). However, this strategy has not been proposed and realized for electrochemical CO2RR.
elements.clean_text: In the process of the electrocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), strong enough binding of the *CO intermediate on the catalytic surface is required to establish sufficient coverage for further reduction or C-C coupling. Experimentally, it was verified that regulating the electronic structure of copper could stabilize the *CO intermediate. Introducing ligands with strong hydrogen-bonding groups (amino and phenolic hydroxyl groups) around metal active sites is another way to stabilize the key intermediates (*COH and *OCCOH). Among them, phenolic hydroxyl groups are not only hydrogen-bond donors but also proton sources to adjust proton delivery and promote hydrogenation. Theoretical calculations showed that there are two potential reaction pathways for the formation of the C-C bond, namely, (a) the dimerization of two *CO and (b) the coupling of *CO with a *CO hydrogenation product (e.g., *COH). In fact, the barrier of a *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH is 0.87 eV (U = 0 V), which is much lower than that (1.15 eV) of *CO dimerization. Thus, adjusting proton delivery to hydrogenate *CO into *COH and then coupling with an adjacent *CO species are beneficial to reduce the energy barrier for forming a C-C bond. Carefully analyzing the molecular structure of the *OCCOH intermediate shows that the C-C distance is about 1.55 Å, and the ∠C-C site is about 108-120°, so the ideal distance between two active sites for forming the *OCCOH species is within 2.78-3.56 Å. Therefore, introducing amino and phenolic hydroxyl groups around the active sites with an appropriate distance may markedly promote the C-C coupling synergistically (c). However, this strategy has not been proposed and realized for electrochemical CO2RR.

elements.content:
Description of Different C–C Coupling Pathways and the Corresponding Energy Barriers: (a) *CO Dimerization Pathways; (b) Coupling of *CO with a Hydrogenated *COH to Form a *OCCOH Intermediate When the Distance between the Metal Active Sites Is Appropriate (2.78–3.56 Å); and (c) CO<sub>2</sub>RR-Favored Local Environment with Proton Sources and Hydrogen-Bond Donors around the Active Sites to Reduce the Coupling Energy Barrier and Promote the C–C Bond Formation<xref ref-type="fn" rid="s1fn1"></xref>

Noted: Cu, Orange; C, Gray; O, Red; N, Blue; H, White.
elements.clean_text: 1  Description of Different C-C Coupling Pathways and the Corresponding Energy Barriers: (a) *CO Dimerization Pathways; (b) Coupling of *CO with a Hydrogenated *COH to Form a *OCCOH Intermediate When the Distance between the Metal Active Sites Is Appropriate (2.78-3.56 Å); and (c) CO2RR-Favored Local Environment with Proton Sources and Hydrogen-Bond Donors around the Active Sites to Reduce the Coupling Energy Barrier and Promote the C-C Bond Formation      a Noted: Cu, Orange; C, Gray; O, Red; N, Blue; H, White.

elements.content:
Noted: Cu, Orange; C, Gray; O, Red; N, Blue; H, White.

As we all know, copper is the most effective catalyst that can yield C1–C2+ products via electrocatalytic CO2RR. However, C1 compounds are usually the dominant products for the reported copper-based nanomaterials, and the selectivities of C2+ products are not satisfactory. To improve the catalytic activity and selectivity of the electroreduction of CO2 to C2+ products, various tailoring strategies have been developed for copper-based catalysts. Despite significant progress, the conversions usually work in high alkaline electrolytes. Notably, under alkaline conditions, CO2 will react with OH– to form carbonates, resulting in increment of whole cell resistance, blocking the gas diffusion channel, and accelerating electrolyte flooding. In addition, the resulting Cu-based nanomaterials with high selectivity for C2+ products usually show complicated morphologies, which present a challenge for mechanistic studies. Developing other well-defined crystalline model Cu-based electrocatalysts to precisely uncover the mechanism of C–C coupling and optimizing the C–C coupling pathway could achieve rational design of more effective CO2RR catalysts for producing C2+ products with higher selectivities.
elements.clean_text:
a Noted: Cu, Orange; C, Gray; O, Red; N, Blue; H, White.  

As we all know, copper is the most effective catalyst that can yield C1-C2+ products via electrocatalytic CO2RR. However, C1 compounds are usually the dominant products for the reported copper-based nanomaterials, and the selectivities of C2+ products are not satisfactory. To improve the catalytic activity and selectivity of the electroreduction of CO2 to C2+ products, various tailoring strategies have been developed for copper-based catalysts. Despite significant progress, the conversions usually work in high alkaline electrolytes. Notably, under alkaline conditions, CO2 will react with OH- to form carbonates, resulting in increment of whole cell resistance, blocking the gas diffusion channel, and accelerating electrolyte flooding. In addition, the resulting Cu-based nanomaterials with high selectivity for C2+ products usually show complicated morphologies, which present a challenge for mechanistic studies. Developing other well-defined crystalline model Cu-based electrocatalysts to precisely uncover the mechanism of C-C coupling and optimizing the C-C coupling pathway could achieve rational design of more effective CO2RR catalysts for producing C2+ products with higher selectivities.

elements.content: With definite structures, designability, and modifiability, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have promising applications in catalysis. In CO2RR, only a few MOFs for electrochemical CO2RR show selectivity toward hydrocarbons, but most of them show instability and conversion into Cu or Cu2O clusters. In fact, Cu–N bonds are more stable than Cu–O bonds; thus, Cu–N bond-based MOFs usually exhibit higher stability. Cu-HITP (HITP = 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene) is a two-dimensional (2D) MOF constructed by HITP linkers and square-planar CuN4 nodes. The 2D layer is further stacked by π–π interactions along the [001] direction to form a rod-like structure with 1D hexagonal channels (). Along the c-axis, the distance between adjacent interlayer Cu sites is 3.4 Å (a,b), which is very suitable as the bi-copper active site for the path of *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH. It has been shown that there may be bare metal sites on the crystal surface of a MOF to serve as the catalytic active sites for CO2RR. Therefore, if the surface of Cu-HITP is also terminated with copper ions, there are countless bi-copper sites along the c-axis on the surface of the Cu-HITP crystal. These bi-copper sites could serve as active sites for CO2RR. Moreover, since it shows high conductivity (ca. 0.2 S m–1), such a 2D structure is beneficial for an electro-catalyst with high activity and high selectivity for CO2RR to give C2+ products. In this work, Cu-HITP was employed to investigate the structure–property relationship for selective conversion of CO2 in a 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte. Interestingly, local proton sources and hydrogen-bond donors are introduced around the bi-copper active sites by coating of polydopamine (PDA) with amino and phenolic hydroxyl groups onto the surface of Cu-HITP particles (a), which promotes the *CO and *COH coupling pathway and increases the selectivity of C2+ products by 33%.

In CO2RR, only a few MOFs for electrochemical CO2RR show selectivity toward hydrocarbons, but most of them show instability and conversion into Cu or Cu2O clusters. In fact, Cu-N bonds are more stable than Cu-O bonds; thus, Cu-N bond-based MOFs usually exhibit higher stability. The 2D layer is further stacked by π-π interactions along the [001] direction to form a rod-like structure with 1D hexagonal channels (). Along the c-axis, the distance between adjacent interlayer Cu sites is 3.4 Å (a,b), which is very suitable as the bi-copper active site for the path of *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH. It has been shown that there may be bare metal sites on the crystal surface of a MOF to serve as the catalytic active sites for CO2RR. (c) HRTEM image along the [100] direction. (d,e) TEM image comparison of Cu-HITP@PDA and Cu-HITP. (Note: Red lines are drawn to guide the eye.) (f) High-angle annular dark-field STEM image of Cu-HITP@PDA and the corresponding elemental mapping of (gold) Cu, (cyan) N, (red) C, and (green) O.

elements.content: A solvothermal reaction of the ligand HITP and hydrated Cu­(NO3)2 at 65 °C gave microcrystalline powder of Cu-HITP (a), and its purity was confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns (Figure S1). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) revealed that black Cu-HITP powders consist of hexagonal, 1–2 μm-long rod-like crystals (b and S2). As shown in the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of Cu-HITP (Figure S2), the microcrystals are rod-like with hexagonal channels along the [001] direction, which is consistent with the crystal structure. Notably, a distance of 3.4 Å between two adjacent layers of Cu-HITP along the [001] direction can be observed in the HRTEM images (b and S2, S4).
elements.clean_text: A solvothermal reaction of the ligand HITP and hydrated Cu(NO3)2 at 65 °C gave microcrystalline powder of Cu-HITP (a), and its purity was confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns (Figure S1). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) revealed that black Cu-HITP powders consist of hexagonal, 1-2 μm-long rod-like crystals (b and S2). As shown in the high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images of Cu-HITP (Figure S2), the microcrystals are rod-like with hexagonal channels along the [001] direction, which is consistent with the crystal structure. Notably, a distance of 3.4 Å between two adjacent layers of Cu-HITP along the [001] direction can be observed in the HRTEM images (b and S2, S4).

elements.content: The catalytic CO2RR performances of Cu-HITP were assessed in a gastight H-type electrochemical cell separated by a proton exchange membrane. The working electrode was prepared by coating the microcrystalline powder of the catalyst onto the glassy carbon electrode with a Nafion (perfluorosulfonic acid-PTFE copolymer) binder. Then, the performance of CO2RR was tested in a CO2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte. The gaseous and liquid products were monitored and analyzed by using online gas chromatography (GC) (Figures S24–S29) and proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra, respectively (Figure S30). The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of Cu-HITP showed that the current density measured in the CO2-saturated electrolyte is significantly higher than that measured in the Ar-saturated electrolyte (Figure S5), suggesting that the intrinsic activity of the catalyst is for CO2RR rather than for the hydrogen evolution reaction. Notably, Cu-HITP shows a high selectivity for ethylene [FE­(C2H4) = 30%] and less hydrogen production [FE­(H2) = 17%] at −1.2 V versus RHE (Figure S6). Combined with liquid-phase products, the FE­(C2+) products (including ethylene, ethanol, and acetic acid) of Cu-HITP (a) reach 42(2)% with a current density of 5.2 mA cm–2 at −1.2 V versus RHE. We also measured the CO2RR performance of the nanosheet sample (Figure S9) of Cu-HITP. Compared to the rod-like sample, the nanosheet sample shows a much poor performance [FE­(C2+) of 14%] of CO2RR to C2+ products. Both the structural analysis (Figure S7) and TEM images (Figures S2 and S8) showed that there are more bi-copper sites on the surface of the rod-like sample, while the nanosheet sample has more CuN4 sites, suggesting that the bi-copper sites () along the c-axis on the surface of the Cu-HITP crystal might be the active sites for CO2RR to give C2+ products. On the one hand, the distance between adjacent Cu sites (d Cu–Cu = 3.4 Å) is very suitable for catalyzing *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH in the low-energy pathway. Additionally, it is possible to improve the FE­(C2+) by providing a CO2RR-favored local environment (with proton sources and hydrogen-bond donors) around the bi-copper active sites.

elements.content: Electrocatalytic performance of Cu-HITP and Cu-HITP@PDA for CO2RR. (a) Comparison of CO2RR performances of Cu-HITP with different PDA coating amounts at −1.2 V vs RHE. (b) Faradaic efficiency (FE) of Cu-HITP@PDA at different potentials (−1.1 to −1.5 V). (c) Comparison of FE­(C2+) between Cu-HITP@PDA and some representative electrocatalysts under neutral conditions (note: C2+ products include C2H4, n-PrOH, EtOH, and CH3COOH).
elements.clean_text: 2  Electrocatalytic performance of Cu-HITP and Cu-HITP@PDA for CO2RR. (a) Comparison of CO2RR performances of Cu-HITP with different PDA coating amounts at -1.2 V vs RHE. (b) Faradaic efficiency (FE) of Cu-HITP@PDA at different potentials (-1.1 to -1.5 V). (c) Comparison of FE(C2+) between Cu-HITP@PDA and some representative electrocatalysts under neutral conditions (note: C2+ products include C2H4, n-PrOH, EtOH, and CH3COOH).

elements.content: With amino (−NH−) and phenolic hydroxyl groups, conductive polymer PDA can be used as hydrogen-bond donors and proton sources at the same time (a and S23). Therefore, coating it on the Cu-HITP surface may significantly increase the C2+ products’ selectivities. With all this in mind, we assembled PDA in situ on the Cu-HITP surface through the self-polymerization reaction of dopamine and fabricated Cu-HITP@PDA samples with different PDA coating amounts at mass ratios of Cu-HITP/dopamine of 10/1, 10/3, 10/5, and 10/7 (Figure S11) to find out the optimal amount of coating. Also, the HRTEM and SEM images of Cu-HITP@PDA (d and S10–S15) showed that the Cu-HITP crystal was coated by a uniform shell, suggesting the existence of PDA. Besides, compared with the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy line scan mode of Cu-HITP, the shell of Cu-HITP@PDA has an O element, suggesting the shell of PDA on the Cu-HITP core (f). The LSV curves show that Cu-HITP@PDA and Cu-HITP exhibit similar current density (Figure S16). As depicted in a, as the amount of PDA coating increased, the yield of CO and CH4 products decreased, while the selectivity of C2+ products increased; especially, the FE of C2H4 was improved from 30.8 to 51% (Figure S32). Furthermore, with the increase in potential, the FE of the C2+ products increased gradually and reached a maximum value of 75(3)% at −1.2 V versus RHE and then decreased (b). Also, the best performance gives 75(3)% FE­(C2+) (C2H4, n-PrOH, EtOH, and CH3COOH), 4(0.39)% FE­(CH4), 3(1.5)% FE­(HCOOH), 0.62(0.23)% FE­(CH3OH), 3(1.1)% FE­(CO), and 13(3.1)% FE­(H2) at −1.2 V versus RHE (b). The FE­(C2+) value of Cu-HITP@PDA is much higher than that of Cu-HITP under the same conditions, indicating that the local chemical environment (local hydrogen bonding and proton sources) formed by the PDA shell around the bi-copper active sites plays a critical role in improving the selectivity of C2+ products. It should be noted that the performance of Cu-HITP@PDA is obviously higher than that of most electrocatalysts and only slightly lower than that of three Cu-based nanomaterials [Re-Cu-I, boron-doped copper, and Cu-polyaniline (PANI)] under neutral conditions in the H-cell (c and Table S2). The definite structure–property relationship established by this well-defined structural model system (Cu-HITP@PDA) can provide more insights on the reaction mechanism for understanding the C–C coupling and optimizing the C–C coupling pathway.

With all this in mind, we assembled PDA in situ on the Cu-HITP surface through the self-polymerization reaction of dopamine and fabricated Cu-HITP@PDA samples with different PDA coating amounts at mass ratios of Cu-HITP/dopamine of 10/1, 10/3, 10/5, and 10/7 (Figure S11) to find out the optimal amount of coating. Also, the best performance gives 75(3)% FE(C2+) (C2H4, n-PrOH, EtOH, and CH3COOH), 4(0.39)% FE(CH4), 3(1.5)% FE(HCOOH), 0.62(0.23)% FE(CH3OH), 3(1.1)% FE(CO), and 13(3.1)% FE(H2) at -1.2 V versus RHE (b). The definite structure-property relationship established by this well-defined structural model system (Cu-HITP@PDA) can provide more insights on the reaction mechanism for understanding the C-C coupling and optimizing the C-C coupling pathway.

elements.content: In order to determine the carbon source of gas products, the 13C isotope-labeling experiments were performed with GC–mass spectrometry (GC–MS). As shown in Figure S41, the peaks at m/z = 30, 17, and 29 are assigned to 13C2H4, 13CH4, and 13CO, respectively, indicating that the carbon source of the reduction products indeed derives from the CO2 used. Moreover, electrolysis with Cu-HITP@PDA as the electrocatalyst in the Ar atmosphere was performed. As being expected, the GC profiles and 1H NMR spectrum demonstrate that no carbon oxygenate or hydrocarbons can be detected (Figures S39 and S40), indicating that the elemental carbon in the catalyst is not involved in the formation of the reduction products.
elements.clean_text: In order to determine the carbon source of gas products, the 13C isotope-labeling experiments were performed with GC-mass spectrometry (GC-MS). As shown in Figure S41, the peaks at m/z = 30, 17, and 29 are assigned to 13C2H4, 13CH4, and 13CO, respectively, indicating that the carbon source of the reduction products indeed derives from the CO2 used. Moreover, electrolysis with Cu-HITP@PDA as the electrocatalyst in the Ar atmosphere was performed. As being expected, the GC profiles and 1H NMR spectrum demonstrate that no carbon oxygenate or hydrocarbons can be detected (Figures S39 and S40), indicating that the elemental carbon in the catalyst is not involved in the formation of the reduction products.

elements.content: The long-term electrolysis at −1.2 V versus RHE for Cu-HITP@PDA indicated that its CO2RR performance can be maintained for at least 10 h (Figure S22). To further confirm the stability of the oxidation state and coordination configuration of Cu­(II) ions, the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of Cu-HITP@PDA were measured at −1.2 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KHCO3 during the first 30 min and after 1 h (). As shown in a,b, no significant change was observed in Cu K-edges during the CO2RR process, indicating that the oxidation state of copper was maintained, and no Cu(0) or Cu­(I) signal was detected during CO2RR. Furthermore, the spectra of extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) of Cu-HITP@PDA showed that the first coordination center peak of 1.96 Å (corresponding to the Cu–N bond) remains unchanged, demonstrating no change in the coordination configuration of Cu­(II) ions throughout the catalytic process (d,e). Notably, according to the PXRD patterns, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy pattern, and SEM and TEM images, the performance (Figure S22), copper oxidation state, morphology, and the structure (Figures S17–S21) of Cu-HITP@PDA could be maintained, and no Cu or Cu2O cluster was generated during electrocatalysis.
elements.clean_text: The long-term electrolysis at -1.2 V versus RHE for Cu-HITP@PDA indicated that its CO2RR performance can be maintained for at least 10 h (Figure S22). To further confirm the stability of the oxidation state and coordination configuration of Cu(II) ions, the X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of Cu-HITP@PDA were measured at -1.2 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KHCO3 during the first 30 min and after 1 h (). As shown in a,b, no significant change was observed in Cu K-edges during the CO2RR process, indicating that the oxidation state of copper was maintained, and no Cu(0) or Cu(I) signal was detected during CO2RR. Furthermore, the spectra of extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) of Cu-HITP@PDA showed that the first coordination center peak of 1.96 Å (corresponding to the Cu-N bond) remains unchanged, demonstrating no change in the coordination configuration of Cu(II) ions throughout the catalytic process (d,e). Notably, according to the PXRD patterns, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy pattern, and SEM and TEM images, the performance (Figure S22), copper oxidation state, morphology, and the structure (Figures S17-S21) of Cu-HITP@PDA could be maintained, and no Cu or Cu2O cluster was generated during electrocatalysis.

elements.content: In situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy characterization of both catalysts and references. (a) Cu K-edge in situ XANES spectra of the Cu-HITP@PDA measured at −1.2 V vs RHE in 0.1 M KHCO3 during the first 30 min and after 1 h. (b) Partially magnified in situ XANES spectra. Bulk Cu, Cu2O, and CuO spectra are plotted as references. (c) Wavelet transform (WT) contour plots of EXAFS for Cu-HITP@PDA. Magnitude (d) and imaginary (e) parts of R′ space EXAFS spectra and fits of the Cu-HITP@PDA sample. Inset: the illustration of the CuN4 coordination motif. Corresponding fitting results are listed in Table S1.
elements.clean_text: 3  In situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy characterization of both catalysts and references. (a) Cu K-edge in situ XANES spectra of the Cu-HITP@PDA measured at -1.2 V vs RHE in 0.1 M KHCO3 during the first 30 min and after 1 h. (b) Partially magnified in situ XANES spectra. Bulk Cu, Cu2O, and CuO spectra are plotted as references. (c) Wavelet transform (WT) contour plots of EXAFS for Cu-HITP@PDA. Magnitude (d) and imaginary (e) parts of R' space EXAFS spectra and fits of the Cu-HITP@PDA sample. Inset: the illustration of the CuN4 coordination motif. Corresponding fitting results are listed in Table S1.

elements.content: In order to ascertain the intermediates during CO2RR, in situ electrochemical attenuated total reflection Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) studies for the catalysts were performed to understand the structure–activity relationship of Cu-HITP during the electrocatalysis process. The in situ FTIR signals were collected at −1.2 V versus RHE in a CO2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte using a home-made ATR-FTIR device (Figure S36). As shown in a, the bands located at 1387 and 1400 cm–1 in the spectra can be assigned to the carboxyl intermediate of *COOH and the bidentate intermediate of *COO, respectively. Also, the band located at 2079 cm–1 can be assigned to chemisorbed CO, namely, *CO (a). Furthermore, the absorption peaks of the *CH2 intermediate (3108 cm–1 for C–H stretch and 995 cm–1 can be assigned to the C–H bending vibration) were observed. Notably, the band at 1150 cm–1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of the *COH intermediate, indicating that the *CO species obtains H and then hydrogenates into a *COH intermediate during the CO2RR process (a,e). Most importantly, the band at 1575 cm–1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of the *OCCOH intermediate. This means that *OCCOH is a key intermediate for Cu-HITP electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to C2+ products.
elements.clean_text: In order to ascertain the intermediates during CO2RR, in situ electrochemical attenuated total reflection Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) studies for the catalysts were performed to understand the structure-activity relationship of Cu-HITP during the electrocatalysis process. The in situ FTIR signals were collected at -1.2 V versus RHE in a CO2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte using a home-made ATR-FTIR device (Figure S36). As shown in a, the bands located at 1387 and 1400 cm-1 in the spectra can be assigned to the carboxyl intermediate of *COOH and the bidentate intermediate of *COO, respectively. Also, the band located at 2079 cm-1 can be assigned to chemisorbed CO, namely, *CO (a). Furthermore, the absorption peaks of the *CH2 intermediate (3108 cm-1 for C-H stretch and 995 cm-1 can be assigned to the C-H bending vibration) were observed. Notably, the band at 1150 cm-1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of the *COH intermediate, indicating that the *CO species obtains H and then hydrogenates into a *COH intermediate during the CO2RR process (a,e). Most importantly, the band at 1575 cm-1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of the *OCCOH intermediate. This means that *OCCOH is a key intermediate for Cu-HITP electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to C2+ products.

elements.content: (a) In situ ATR-FTIR spectra on Cu-HITP collected at −1.2 V vs RHE in the CO2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte. (b) Free energy diagram for forming the C–C bond on the Cu-HITP model. (c) Comparison of the corresponding energies for the formation of *OCCOH through the coupling of *CO and *COH intermediates on the surfaces of different catalysts. (d) Optimized structures of the coupling reaction intermediates involved. (e) Catalytic mechanism of Cu-HITP@PDA for the formation of C2H4 and EtOH.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) In situ ATR-FTIR spectra on Cu-HITP collected at -1.2 V vs RHE in the CO2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte. (b) Free energy diagram for forming the C-C bond on the Cu-HITP model. (c) Comparison of the corresponding energies for the formation of *OCCOH through the coupling of *CO and *COH intermediates on the surfaces of different catalysts. (d) Optimized structures of the coupling reaction intermediates involved. (e) Catalytic mechanism of Cu-HITP@PDA for the formation of C2H4 and EtOH.

elements.content: Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were used to simulate the energy of the reaction process based on the intermediates revealed by in situ ATR-FTIR (b,d). The DFT calculation results show that the rate-determining step is the conversion of *CO to *COH with a reaction energy of ca. 0.95 eV; thus, under the electric potentials applied in the current work (−1.1 to −1.5 V), this step is likely to occur (b). Notably, the formation of the key intermediate *OCCOH revealed by in situ IR spectra just has a very low reaction energy of −0.74 eV. Such a low coupling reaction energy indicates that it is easy to form a C–C bond on the Cu-HITP surface through the *OCCOH intermediate. Furthermore, we also calculated other possible C–C coupling mechanisms. As shown in Figure S45, the DFT calculation results show that the direct formation of *OCCO intermediates from two *CO species on the Cu-HITP surface is thermodynamically forbidden because the distance between two adjacent *CO species is 2.72 Å. Similarly, the distance between two intermediates *CO and *CHO is 3.25 Å, which does not conform to the covalent bonding rules and cannot form an effective C–C bond. In other words, the coupling of *CO with *COH to generate *OCCOH is the most thermodynamically dominant pathway to form the C–C bond.
elements.clean_text: Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were used to simulate the energy of the reaction process based on the intermediates revealed by in situ ATR-FTIR (b,d). The DFT calculation results show that the rate-determining step is the conversion of *CO to *COH with a reaction energy of ca. 0.95 eV; thus, under the electric potentials applied in the current work (-1.1 to -1.5 V), this step is likely to occur (b). Notably, the formation of the key intermediate *OCCOH revealed by in situ IR spectra just has a very low reaction energy of -0.74 eV. Such a low coupling reaction energy indicates that it is easy to form a C-C bond on the Cu-HITP surface through the *OCCOH intermediate. Furthermore, we also calculated other possible C-C coupling mechanisms. As shown in Figure S45, the DFT calculation results show that the direct formation of *OCCO intermediates from two *CO species on the Cu-HITP surface is thermodynamically forbidden because the distance between two adjacent *CO species is 2.72 Å. Similarly, the distance between two intermediates *CO and *CHO is 3.25 Å, which does not conform to the covalent bonding rules and cannot form an effective C-C bond. In other words, the coupling of *CO with *COH to generate *OCCOH is the most thermodynamically dominant pathway to form the C-C bond.

elements.content: We further studied the C–C coupling between the *CO and *COH species on the classical Cu(100) and Cu(111) surfaces. Notably, the reaction energy for the coupling of *CO and *COH species to form a C–C bond is −0.74 eV on the Cu-HITP surfaces, which is lower than that for Cu(100) and Cu(111) facets (c,d). Furthermore, c shows that for the step of *CO + *COH → *OCCOH, the free energy barrier on Cu-HITP is the lowest compared to those on the Cu(111) and Cu(100) surfaces. This phenomenon might be due to the fact that the distances between adjacent Cu sites of Cu(100) and Cu(111) facets are 2.54 and 2.56 Å (d), respectively; they are shorter than the ideal distance (2.78–3.56 Å) between two active sites for forming *OCCOH. This implies that compared to the Cu(100) and Cu(111) facets, the distance (3.4 Å) between active sites in Cu-HITP is more appropriate for the low-energy pathway of *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH.
elements.clean_text: We further studied the C-C coupling between the *CO and *COH species on the classical Cu(100) and Cu(111) surfaces. Notably, the reaction energy for the coupling of *CO and *COH species to form a C-C bond is -0.74 eV on the Cu-HITP surfaces, which is lower than that for Cu(100) and Cu(111) facets (c,d). Furthermore, c shows that for the step of *CO + *COH → *OCCOH, the free energy barrier on Cu-HITP is the lowest compared to those on the Cu(111) and Cu(100) surfaces. This phenomenon might be due to the fact that the distances between adjacent Cu sites of Cu(100) and Cu(111) facets are 2.54 and 2.56 Å (d), respectively; they are shorter than the ideal distance (2.78-3.56 Å) between two active sites for forming *OCCOH. This implies that compared to the Cu(100) and Cu(111) facets, the distance (3.4 Å) between active sites in Cu-HITP is more appropriate for the low-energy pathway of *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH.

elements.content: To investigate the roles of the PDA shell in the CO2RR activity, we synthesized PANI- [only amino (−NH−) groups on phenyl rings] and poly­(p-vinylphenol)- (only phenolic hydroxy group on phenyl rings) (Figure S23) decorated Cu-HITP to compare the catalytic selectivity for CO2RR (Figures S31 and S32). As shown in Figure S32, the CH4 product on Cu-HITP@Poly­(p-vinylphenol) increases slightly, while the selectivity of FE­(CO) is greatly reduced, compared with that of Cu-HITP, reflecting that the large amount of adsorbed H provided by the phenolic hydroxyl group can promote *CO hydrogenation. For Cu-HITP@PANI, its selectivity of C2+ products is significantly higher than that of Cu-HITP but lower than that of Cu-HITP@PDA (Figure S31), suggesting that the amino groups may act as hydrogen-bond donors to stabilize certain key intermediates in the formation of C2+ products. Also, the selectivity of C2+ for Cu-HITP@PDA is significantly increased compared to Cu-HITP@Poly­(p-vinylphenol) and Cu-HITP@PANI (Figure S31). This phenomenon indicated that the phenolic hydroxy could provide protons to promote the hydrogenation of *CO to produce *COH (e), and the amino group may act as a hydrogen-bond donor to stabilize the key intermediates (*COH and *OCOH). Such a hypothesis was confirmed by the in situ ATR-FTIR spectra of Cu-HITP and Cu-HITP@PDA. As shown in Figures S37 and S38, compared with Cu-HITP, the peaks of *COH and *OCCOH intermediates of Cu-HITP@PDA (located at 1095 and 1549 cm–1, respectively) are red-shifted, which implied that the formation of hydrogen bonds between the functional/amino groups on PDA and the intermediates leads to weakening of the stretching vibration. On the other hand, the signal of the *CO intermediate was not captured, reflecting that the large amount of adsorbed H provided by the phenolic hydroxyl group promotes *CO hydrogenation to *COH, which leads to a decrease in the *CO intermediates. Therefore, the synergistic effect of the amino and the phenolic hydroxyl groups in Cu-HITP@PDA could remarkably increase the selectivity of C2+ products.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the roles of the PDA shell in the CO2RR activity, we synthesized PANI- [only amino (-NH-) groups on phenyl rings] and poly(p-vinylphenol)- (only phenolic hydroxy group on phenyl rings) (Figure S23) decorated Cu-HITP to compare the catalytic selectivity for CO2RR (Figures S31 and S32). As shown in Figure S32, the CH4 product on Cu-HITP@Poly(p-vinylphenol) increases slightly, while the selectivity of FE(CO) is greatly reduced, compared with that of Cu-HITP, reflecting that the large amount of adsorbed H provided by the phenolic hydroxyl group can promote *CO hydrogenation. For Cu-HITP@PANI, its selectivity of C2+ products is significantly higher than that of Cu-HITP but lower than that of Cu-HITP@PDA (Figure S31), suggesting that the amino groups may act as hydrogen-bond donors to stabilize certain key intermediates in the formation of C2+ products. Also, the selectivity of C2+ for Cu-HITP@PDA is significantly increased compared to Cu-HITP@Poly(p-vinylphenol) and Cu-HITP@PANI (Figure S31). This phenomenon indicated that the phenolic hydroxy could provide protons to promote the hydrogenation of *CO to produce *COH (e), and the amino group may act as a hydrogen-bond donor to stabilize the key intermediates (*COH and *OCOH). Such a hypothesis was confirmed by the in situ ATR-FTIR spectra of Cu-HITP and Cu-HITP@PDA. As shown in Figures S37 and S38, compared with Cu-HITP, the peaks of *COH and *OCCOH intermediates of Cu-HITP@PDA (located at 1095 and 1549 cm-1, respectively) are red-shifted, which implied that the formation of hydrogen bonds between the functional/amino groups on PDA and the intermediates leads to weakening of the stretching vibration. On the other hand, the signal of the *CO intermediate was not captured, reflecting that the large amount of adsorbed H provided by the phenolic hydroxyl group promotes *CO hydrogenation to *COH, which leads to a decrease in the *CO intermediates. Therefore, the synergistic effect of the amino and the phenolic hydroxyl groups in Cu-HITP@PDA could remarkably increase the selectivity of C2+ products.

elements.content: Compared with the H-type cell, CO2 gas can flow continuously through the gas-diffusion layer in a flow cell, thus facilitating the mass transfer of CO2 to the electrocatalyst and leading to an increase in current density. The LSV curves of Cu-HITP@PDA in a three-electrode flow cell with a gas diffusion electrode as the working electrode in a 0.1 M KHCO3 aqueous solution were also measured. At −1.2 V versus RHE, the current density increased to 55 mA cm–2 and reached 130 mA cm–2 at −1.5 V versus RHE (Figure S46), and no obvious degradation was observed at 55 mA cm–2 over 10 h of continuous operation (Figure S47). In a 1.0 M KOH aqueous solution, benefitting from diverse functions (influencing Bader charge of catalyst surfaces and tuning the catalytic pathway by nucleophilic reactions with surface intermediates) of OH– ions, the current density could even reach 310 mA cm–2 (−1.2 V vs RHE), which is over the commercially relevant current density of 300 mA cm–2. Importantly, after 10 h of electrolysis at a current density of 310 mA cm–2, no significant decay was observed (Figure S47).
elements.clean_text: Compared with the H-type cell, CO2 gas can flow continuously through the gas-diffusion layer in a flow cell, thus facilitating the mass transfer of CO2 to the electrocatalyst and leading to an increase in current density. The LSV curves of Cu-HITP@PDA in a three-electrode flow cell with a gas diffusion electrode as the working electrode in a 0.1 M KHCO3 aqueous solution were also measured. At -1.2 V versus RHE, the current density increased to 55 mA cm-2 and reached 130 mA cm-2 at -1.5 V versus RHE (Figure S46), and no obvious degradation was observed at 55 mA cm-2 over 10 h of continuous operation (Figure S47). In a 1.0 M KOH aqueous solution, benefitting from diverse functions (influencing Bader charge of catalyst surfaces and tuning the catalytic pathway by nucleophilic reactions with surface intermediates) of OH- ions, the current density could even reach 310 mA cm-2 (-1.2 V vs RHE), which is over the commercially relevant current density of 300 mA cm-2. Importantly, after 10 h of electrolysis at a current density of 310 mA cm-2, no significant decay was observed (Figure S47).

elements.content: In summary, focusing on the effects of the distance between the adjacent catalytic sites and the local chemical environment on the selectivity of CO2RR, we reported a new catalyst Cu-HITP@PDA for CO2RR, which achieved an excellent performance for electroreduction of CO2 into C2+ products. Our results indicate that the appropriate distance between adjacent Cu sites (d Cu–Cu = 3.4 Å) is beneficial to the pathway of *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH, and this pathway can be facilitated by putting the coat of PDA onto the surface of Cu-HITP to modify the local chemical environment with enhanced hydrogen-bonding donors and proton sources. Such an integration of the rational active site structure and post-modification of its local chemical environment may provide a new strategy for optimizing the FE of C2+ products.
elements.clean_text: In summary, focusing on the effects of the distance between the adjacent catalytic sites and the local chemical environment on the selectivity of CO2RR, we reported a new catalyst Cu-HITP@PDA for CO2RR, which achieved an excellent performance for electroreduction of CO2 into C2+ products. Our results indicate that the appropriate distance between adjacent Cu sites (d Cu-Cu = 3.4 Å) is beneficial to the pathway of *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH, and this pathway can be facilitated by putting the coat of PDA onto the surface of Cu-HITP to modify the local chemical environment with enhanced hydrogen-bonding donors and proton sources. Such an integration of the rational active site structure and post-modification of its local chemical environment may provide a new strategy for optimizing the FE of C2+ products.

cln_elements.content:
Conversion from CO2 to the more desirable and valuable C2+ products under neutral conditions is important for the development of energy and the environment, but it is a challenging work. In this work, we demonstrate that the bi-copper sites on the crystal surface of a metal–organic framework Cu-HITP (HITP = 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene) are very suitable for catalyzing the low-energy pathway of *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH. The in situ infrared spectroscopy, theoretic calculations, and controlled experiments show that polydopamine coating of Cu-HITP could provide a carbon dioxide reduction reaction-favored local environment with proton sources and hydrogen-bond donors around the bi-copper active sites to promote *CO hydrogenation and stabilize the key intermediates (*COH and *OCCOH), resulting in a high selectivity of the C2+ reduced products [Faradaic efficiency (C2+) of 75(3)%, Faradaic efficiency (C2H4) of 51(1)%] in the KHCO3 electrolyte. This work provides an insight into the catalytic activity on the surface of metal–organic frameworks and the local environment for electroreduction of CO2 to C2+ products.

The catalytic CO2RR performances of Cu-HITP were assessed in a gastight H-type electrochemical cell separated by a proton exchange membrane. The working electrode was prepared by coating the microcrystalline powder of the catalyst onto the glassy carbon electrode with a Nafion (perfluorosulfonic acid-PTFE copolymer) binder. Then, the performance of CO2RR was tested in a CO2-saturated 0.1 M KHCO3 electrolyte. The gaseous and liquid products were monitored and analyzed by using online gas chromatography (GC) (Figures S24–S29) and proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectra, respectively (Figure S30). The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of Cu-HITP showed that the current density measured in the CO2-saturated electrolyte is significantly higher than that measured in the Ar-saturated electrolyte (Figure S5), suggesting that the intrinsic activity of the catalyst is for CO2RR rather than for the hydrogen evolution reaction. Notably, Cu-HITP shows a high selectivity for ethylene [FE­(C2H4) = 30%] and less hydrogen production [FE­(H2) = 17%] at −1.2 V versus RHE (Figure S6). Combined with liquid-phase products, the FE­(C2+) products (including ethylene, ethanol, and acetic acid) of Cu-HITP (a) reach 42(2)% with a current density of 5.2 mA cm–2 at −1.2 V versus RHE. We also measured the CO2RR performance of the nanosheet sample (Figure S9) of Cu-HITP. Compared to the rod-like sample, the nanosheet sample shows a much poor performance [FE­(C2+) of 14%] of CO2RR to C2+ products. Both the structural analysis (Figure S7) and TEM images (Figures S2 and S8) showed that there are more bi-copper sites on the surface of the rod-like sample, while the nanosheet sample has more CuN4 sites, suggesting that the bi-copper sites () along the c-axis on the surface of the Cu-HITP crystal might be the active sites for CO2RR to give C2+ products. On the one hand, the distance between adjacent Cu sites (d Cu–Cu = 3.4 Å) is very suitable for catalyzing *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH in the low-energy pathway. Additionally, it is possible to improve the FE­(C2+) by providing a CO2RR-favored local environment (with proton sources and hydrogen-bond donors) around the bi-copper active sites.

With amino (−NH−) and phenolic hydroxyl groups, conductive polymer PDA can be used as hydrogen-bond donors and proton sources at the same time (a and S23). Therefore, coating it on the Cu-HITP surface may significantly increase the C2+ products’ selectivities. With all this in mind, we assembled PDA in situ on the Cu-HITP surface through the self-polymerization reaction of dopamine and fabricated Cu-HITP@PDA samples with different PDA coating amounts at mass ratios of Cu-HITP/dopamine of 10/1, 10/3, 10/5, and 10/7 (Figure S11) to find out the optimal amount of coating. Also, the HRTEM and SEM images of Cu-HITP@PDA (d and S10–S15) showed that the Cu-HITP crystal was coated by a uniform shell, suggesting the existence of PDA. Besides, compared with the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy line scan mode of Cu-HITP, the shell of Cu-HITP@PDA has an O element, suggesting the shell of PDA on the Cu-HITP core (f). The LSV curves show that Cu-HITP@PDA and Cu-HITP exhibit similar current density (Figure S16). As depicted in a, as the amount of PDA coating increased, the yield of CO and CH4 products decreased, while the selectivity of C2+ products increased; especially, the FE of C2H4 was improved from 30.8 to 51% (Figure S32). Furthermore, with the increase in potential, the FE of the C2+ products increased gradually and reached a maximum value of 75(3)% at −1.2 V versus RHE and then decreased (b). Also, the best performance gives 75(3)% FE­(C2+) (C2H4, n-PrOH, EtOH, and CH3COOH), 4(0.39)% FE­(CH4), 3(1.5)% FE­(HCOOH), 0.62(0.23)% FE­(CH3OH), 3(1.1)% FE­(CO), and 13(3.1)% FE­(H2) at −1.2 V versus RHE (b). The FE­(C2+) value of Cu-HITP@PDA is much higher than that of Cu-HITP under the same conditions, indicating that the local chemical environment (local hydrogen bonding and proton sources) formed by the PDA shell around the bi-copper active sites plays a critical role in improving the selectivity of C2+ products. It should be noted that the performance of Cu-HITP@PDA is obviously higher than that of most electrocatalysts and only slightly lower than that of three Cu-based nanomaterials [Re-Cu-I, boron-doped copper, and Cu-polyaniline (PANI)] under neutral conditions in the H-cell (c and Table S2). The definite structure–property relationship established by this well-defined structural model system (Cu-HITP@PDA) can provide more insights on the reaction mechanism for understanding the C–C coupling and optimizing the C–C coupling pathway.

Compared with the H-type cell, CO2 gas can flow continuously through the gas-diffusion layer in a flow cell, thus facilitating the mass transfer of CO2 to the electrocatalyst and leading to an increase in current density. The LSV curves of Cu-HITP@PDA in a three-electrode flow cell with a gas diffusion electrode as the working electrode in a 0.1 M KHCO3 aqueous solution were also measured. At −1.2 V versus RHE, the current density increased to 55 mA cm–2 and reached 130 mA cm–2 at −1.5 V versus RHE (Figure S46), and no obvious degradation was observed at 55 mA cm–2 over 10 h of continuous operation (Figure S47). In a 1.0 M KOH aqueous solution, benefitting from diverse functions (influencing Bader charge of catalyst surfaces and tuning the catalytic pathway by nucleophilic reactions with surface intermediates) of OH– ions, the current density could even reach 310 mA cm–2 (−1.2 V vs RHE), which is over the commercially relevant current density of 300 mA cm–2. Importantly, after 10 h of electrolysis at a current density of 310 mA cm–2, no significant decay was observed (Figure S47).

Conversion from CO2 to the more desirable and valuable C2+ products under neutral conditions is important for the development of energy and the environment, but it is a challenging work. In this work, we demonstrate that the bi-copper sites on the crystal surface of a metal-organic framework Cu-HITP (HITP = 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene) are very suitable for catalyzing the low-energy pathway of *CO coupling with *COH to form *OCCOH. The in situ infrared spectroscopy, theoretic calculations, and controlled experiments show that polydopamine coating of Cu-HITP could provide a carbon dioxide reduction reaction-favored local environment with proton sources and hydrogen-bond donors around the bi-copper active sites to promote *CO hydrogenation and stabilize the key intermediates (*COH and *OCCOH), resulting in a high selectivity of the C2+ reduced products [Faradaic efficiency (C2+) of 75(3)%, Faradaic efficiency (C2H4) of 51(1)%] in the KHCO3 electrolyte. This work provides an insight into the catalytic activity on the surface of metal-organic frameworks and the local environment for electroreduction of CO2 to C2+ products.

The catalytic CO2RR performances of Cu-HITP were assessed in a gastight H-type electrochemical cell separated by a proton exchange membrane. Additionally, it is possible to improve the FE(C2+) by providing a CO2RR-favored local environment (with proton sources and hydrogen-bond donors) around the bi-copper active sites. 

With amino (-NH-) and phenolic hydroxyl groups, conductive polymer PDA can be used as hydrogen-bond donors and proton sources at the same time (a and S23). Therefore, coating it on the Cu-HITP surface may significantly increase the C2+ products' selectivities. With all this in mind, we assembled PDA in situ on the Cu-HITP surface through the self-polymerization reaction of dopamine and fabricated Cu-HITP@PDA samples with different PDA coating amounts at mass ratios of Cu-HITP/dopamine of 10/1, 10/3, 10/5, and 10/7 (Figure S11) to find out the optimal amount of coating. Also, the HRTEM and SEM images of Cu-HITP@PDA (d and S10-S15) showed that the Cu-HITP crystal was coated by a uniform shell, suggesting the existence of PDA. Besides, compared with the energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy line scan mode of Cu-HITP, the shell of Cu-HITP@PDA has an O element, suggesting the shell of PDA on the Cu-HITP core (f). The LSV curves show that Cu-HITP@PDA and Cu-HITP exhibit similar current density (Figure S16). As depicted in a, as the amount of PDA coating increased, the yield of CO and CH4 products decreased, while the selectivity of C2+ products increased; especially, the FE of C2H4 was improved from 30.8 to 51% (Figure S32). Furthermore, with the increase in potential, the FE of the C2+ products increased gradually and reached a maximum value of 75(3)% at -1.2 V versus RHE and then decreased (b). Also, the best performance gives 75(3)% FE(C2+) (C2H4, n-PrOH, EtOH, and CH3COOH), 4(0.39)% FE(CH4), 3(1.5)% FE(HCOOH), 0.62(0.23)% FE(CH3OH), 3(1.1)% FE(CO), and 13(3.1)% FE(H2) at -1.2 V versus RHE (b). The FE(C2+) value of Cu-HITP@PDA is much higher than that of Cu-HITP under the same conditions, indicating that the local chemical environment (local hydrogen bonding and proton sources) formed by the PDA shell around the bi-copper active sites plays a critical role in improving the selectivity of C2+ products. It should be noted that the performance of Cu-HITP@PDA is obviously higher than that of most electrocatalysts and only slightly lower than that of three Cu-based nanomaterials [Re-Cu-I, boron-doped copper, and Cu-polyaniline (PANI)] under neutral conditions in the H-cell (c and Table S2). The definite structure-property relationship established by this well-defined structural model system (Cu-HITP@PDA) can provide more insights on the reaction mechanism for understanding the C-C coupling and optimizing the C-C coupling pathway.

Compared with the H-type cell, CO2 gas can flow continuously through the gas-diffusion layer in a flow cell, thus facilitating the mass transfer of CO2 to the electrocatalyst and leading to an increase in current density. The LSV curves of Cu-HITP@PDA in a three-electrode flow cell with a gas diffusion electrode as the working electrode in a 0.1 M KHCO3 aqueous solution were also measured. At -1.2 V versus RHE, the current density increased to 55 mA cm-2 and reached 130 mA cm-2 at -1.5 V versus RHE (Figure S46), and no obvious degradation was observed at 55 mA cm-2 over 10 h of continuous operation (Figure S47). In a 1.0 M KOH aqueous solution, benefitting from diverse functions (influencing Bader charge of catalyst surfaces and tuning the catalytic pathway by nucleophilic reactions with surface intermediates) of OH- ions, the current density could even reach 310 mA cm-2 (-1.2 V vs RHE), which is over the commercially relevant current density of 300 mA cm-2. Importantly, after 10 h of electrolysis at a current density of 310 mA cm-2, no significant decay was observed (Figure S47).

metadata.title:
Polydopamine Coating of a Metal–Organic Framework
with Bi-Copper Sites for Highly Selective Electroreduction of CO2 to C2+ Products
